docs.snippet: The neighbors are turning into billionaires again.    At least two of them this time. Young fellows, in their early 30's. Clean cut. With nice smiles, and apparent social consciences to boot....
docs.lead_paragraph: The neighbors are turning into billionaires again. At least two of them this time. Young fellows, in their early 30's. Clean cut. With nice smiles, and apparent social consciences to boot.

headline.main: Silicon Valley Looks to Google for Signs of a New Boom

docs.abstract: Silicon Valley residents express guarded optimism over disclosure that Google, Internet search engine company, will go public; Google public offering appears to offer symbolic gesture of economic revival in region; photos (M)

byline.original: By MATT RICHTEL and CAROLYN MARSHALL

docs.snippet: A news analysis article in Business Day yesterday about Google's filing for an initial public offering gave an incorrect age in some copies for its chief executive, Eric Schmidt. He is 49, not 48....
docs.lead_paragraph: A news analysis article in Business Day yesterday about Google's filing for an initial public offering gave an incorrect age in some copies for its chief executive, Eric Schmidt. He is 49, not 48.

headline.main: Corrections

docs.abstract: April 30 analysis about Google's filing for initial public offering gave incorrect age for its chief executive Eric Schmidt; he is 49

docs.snippet: The plan by Google to auction its shares may represent a challenge to Wall Street but the striking success of its Internet advertising business poses perhaps an even greater threat to Madison Avenue.    Unlike conventional advertising, to which va...
docs.lead_paragraph: The plan by Google to auction its shares may represent a challenge to Wall Street but the striking success of its Internet advertising business poses perhaps an even greater threat to Madison Avenue. Unlike conventional advertising, to which vast creative effort is devoted to make it funny or pithy or just downright annoying enough to attract attention, an Internet search engine like Google or Yahoo already has access to users looking for something in particular. Companies with a commercial message can easily reach a vast collection of people one by one who are actually interested in what they have to sell.

headline.main: Google Poses A Challenge For Usual Ad Outlets

docs.abstract: Striking success of Internet advertising business is seen as threat to advertising industry, which puts vast creative effort into making advertising funny or pithy or just downright annoying enough to attract attention; Internet search engines like Google or Yahoo already have access to users looking for something in particular and can offer companies with commercial message vast collection of people one by one who are actually interested in what they have to sell; online advertisers can attract buyers relatively cheaply without blaring message and expensive Madison Avenue agency to create it; most ads on Google are simply a few words of text set to right of main search results; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Google's public offering statement reads like part financial document, part populist manifesto, emphasizing the company's intention to stay true to long-term values, not just short-term profits. Equally unusual is the company's decision to sell sh...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google's public offering statement reads like part financial document, part populist manifesto, emphasizing the company's intention to stay true to long-term values, not just short-term profits. Equally unusual is the company's decision to sell shares to investors through a public auction. But while Google's stated goals and the auction process may be intriguing to investors, many analysts say that Google -- the Web search engine company with an offbeat corporate culture and big financial power -- is unlikely to provide a blueprint for going public for other start-up companies. In addition, many venture capitalists said they did not expect, or even want, Google to inspire a spate of new public offerings if new companies are not yet ready.

headline.main: Analysts Doubt Public Offering Of Google Is a Bellwether

docs.abstract: Google's unusual decision to sell shares to investors through public auction may be intriguing to investors, but many analysts doubt if Google will provide blueprint for going public for other start-up companies; many venture capitalists say they do not expect, or even want, Google to inspire a spate of new public offerings if new companies are not yet ready (M)

docs.snippet: It wasn't a mistake. That newspaper you received Friday reporting that two young Stanford graduates have decided to become instant billionaires by taking their Internet company public was not some reprint from the late 90's.    It sure read like o...
docs.lead_paragraph: It wasn't a mistake. That newspaper you received Friday reporting that two young Stanford graduates have decided to become instant billionaires by taking their Internet company public was not some reprint from the late 90's. It sure read like one, though, including the pledge by Google's founders -- Sergey Brin and Larry Page -- that their one-of-a-kind company with the ''Don't Be Evil'' motto will remain committed to making the world a better place. Such idealistic talk out of Silicon Valley, so seemingly empowering back in 1999, seems embarrassingly naïve now that the party's ended, at least for the rest of us.

headline.main: Googling Google

docs.abstract: Editorial on decision of Google founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page to take their Internet company public; holds that investors should not pay too much attention to hype about Google's auction-like initial public offering

docs.snippet: MATTHEW DIFFEE, a 34-year-old cartoonist from Brooklyn, distinctly remembers when he came to believe he had a shot at becoming a real New Yorker cartoonist. It was around 11:30 a.m. on a Tuesday at the offices of The New Yorker, the appointed time...
docs.lead_paragraph: MATTHEW DIFFEE, a 34-year-old cartoonist from Brooklyn, distinctly remembers when he came to believe he had a shot at becoming a real New Yorker cartoonist. It was around 11:30 a.m. on a Tuesday at the offices of The New Yorker, the appointed time at which, for the better part of 50 years, cartoonists have shown up for the ritual submission of their rough drawings to the magazine's cartoon editor -- these days, Robert Mankoff. Mr. Diffee crossed paths with an older cartoonist emerging from Mr. Mankoff's office, looking as though he'd seen a ghost. Mr. Mankoff, the cartoonist confessed, had given him an ultimatum: no more fedoras in his cartoons. ''The look on his face was as though it hadn't occurred to him not to draw people with hats,'' Mr. Diffee said. ''I don't own a hat. I've never drawn a hat, and if I ever had to draw a fedora I'd have to Google it. So I thought, 'Maybe I'll be O.K.' ''

headline.main: Sex With Einstein? Yes, in the New Yorker

docs.abstract: Article on new generation of cartoonists, mostly in their 30's, who draw classic single-panel cartoons for New Yorker magazine; cartoon editor Robert Mankoff, noting that many of magazine's established cartoonists are in their 70's and 80's, says magazine is urgently grooming new talent; cartoonists Matthew Diffee, 34, C Covert Darbyshire, 32, Carolita Johnson, 39, and Marisa Acocella, 43, comment; photos; cartoons (M)

docs.snippet: IN the letter last Thursday that announced their plans to sell shares to the public, Google's founders were not bashful about the role they see for their company in the information utopia they hope to build.    ''Searching and organizing all the w...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN the letter last Thursday that announced their plans to sell shares to the public, Google's founders were not bashful about the role they see for their company in the information utopia they hope to build. ''Searching and organizing all the world's information,'' the letter stated, is ''an unusually important task that should be carried out by a company that is trustworthy and interested in the public good.''

headline.main: The World: Search for Tomorrow; Is a Do-Gooder Company a Good Thing?

docs.abstract: Internet observers question whether Google, which plans to sell shares to public, will be able to adhere to its famous corporate ethos 'don't do evil' with its role as Internet's chief gatekeeper bolstered by several billion dollars stock sale is expected to raise; say public would do well to scrutinize effects of Google's outsize influence, whether or not it adheres to its promise of trustworthiness; photo (M)

docs.snippet: THE fervent interest that Google's planned stock offering has generated is only the latest piece of evidence that many investors have already shrugged off one of the worst bear markets in history.     For the first time since the collapse of the N...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE fervent interest that Google's planned stock offering has generated is only the latest piece of evidence that many investors have already shrugged off one of the worst bear markets in history. For the first time since the collapse of the Nasdaq stock market in 2000, investors are clamoring to give billions of dollars to a company that is only a few years old and whose stock may not perform well even if its business booms. The company's potential is enormous, but so are its risks.

headline.main: Yesterday's Back! At Last, an I.P.O. To Drool Over

docs.abstract: Fervent interest in initial public offeri

docs.snippet: As far as John Doerr is concerned, the Internet frenzy of the late 1990's was not a bubble. No, to Mr. Doerr, a prominent venture capitalist in Silicon Valley, it was the ''Great American Boom.''     ''It was a good thing,'' he said in an intervie...
docs.lead_paragraph: As far as John Doerr is concerned, the Internet frenzy of the late 1990's was not a bubble. No, to Mr. Doerr, a prominent venture capitalist in Silicon Valley, it was the ''Great American Boom.'' ''It was a good thing,'' he said in an interview last month. ''It made the American economy bigger. It raised incomes for everybody. It made us more of a leader in the world in all respects.''

headline.main: Investment Engines in Search of Their Next Moves

docs.abstract: John Doerr, whose venture capital firm, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, is likely to reap huge profit from its $12.5 million 1999 investment in Google Internet search engine, says long-term potential of Internet is still underappreciated, interview; remains huge presence in Silicon Valley despite his Internet losses, with Kleiner's flops overshadowed by its financial successes; entrepreneurs who got money from Kleiner say Doerr's name lent level of seriousness to their companies and his ties and strategic vision improved their prospects; say firm's lower-profile partners also played key roles; photos (M)

docs.snippet: Next on Google's to-do list: Microsoft?    Perhaps the most glaring omission from Google's remarkable ''owner's manual'' for its initial public offering, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, is that the company, operator of...
docs.lead_paragraph: Next on Google's to-do list: Microsoft? Perhaps the most glaring omission from Google's remarkable ''owner's manual'' for its initial public offering, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, is that the company, operator of the leading search engine, gave prospective investors virtually no hint of where it was headed.

headline.main: Why Google Is Peering Out, At Microsoft

docs.abstract: News analysis discusses future direction of Google, a topic Google omitted from its filing for initial public stock offering; holds Google has secret plans to extend information-searching in many directions; says it is moving down to confront Microsoft from its giant computing resources, world's largest, as Microsoft moves up from its monopoly Windows desktop operating system to so-called Web-based services; says two companies will likely compete over new and immature markets (M)

docs.snippet: As the symbol of one era of initial public offerings faces the possibility of prison, a new era that rejects the excesses of the past may be starting.    For a few years at the height of the technology boom, Frank P. Quattrone was the most powerfu...
docs.lead_paragraph: As the symbol of one era of initial public offerings faces the possibility of prison, a new era that rejects the excesses of the past may be starting. For a few years at the height of the technology boom, Frank P. Quattrone was the most powerful investment banker, and among the most powerful people, in Silicon Valley. It was not just that his decision to bring a company public could make its founders wealthy beyond ordinary people's imaginations. He had the power to hand out wealth to others just by allowing them to buy the stock he was selling.

headline.main: Google May Have Pre-empted Regulators on Public Offerings

docs.abstract: Google Inc's coming public offering, which will be conducted as auction instead of traditional allocation, process run by bankers, could foist change on Wall Street and cut into its profits; photos (Market Place column) (M)

docs.snippet: It's not Google, by any stretch. But the planned stock offering next month of Germany's largest retail bank, Postbank, promises to be the biggest initial public offering in this country in years, and it could resuscitate a moribund market for init...
docs.lead_paragraph: It's not Google, by any stretch. But the planned stock offering next month of Germany's largest retail bank, Postbank, promises to be the biggest initial public offering in this country in years, and it could resuscitate a moribund market for initial offerings. On Thursday, Postbank's parent, Deutsche Post, announced new details about the offering and damped some rumors that have swirled around the share sale. Deutsche Post will list up to 49.9 percent of Postbank's shares on June 21, the postal company's chief executive, Klaus Zumwinkel, said.

headline.main: German Bank Set to Test Stock Climate

docs.abstract: Planned stock offering on June 21 of Germany's largest retail bank Postbank promises to be biggest initial public offering in Germany in years; Deutsche Post, Postbank's parent, announces new details about offering and dampens some rumors that have swirled around share sale; Deutsche Post's chief executive Klaus Zumwinkel says company will list up to 49.9 percent of Postbank's shares with value of $6.1 billion; denies report that he held talks with Deutsche Bank about its acquiring large stake in Postbank; Postbank chairman Wulf von Schimmelmann comments; photo (M)

docs.snippet: IF it's true, as President Calvin Coolidge famously declared, that the business of America is business, then the national conversation about where business is going says a lot about where the country is going. And the business conversation has cha...
docs.lead_paragraph: IF it's true, as President Calvin Coolidge famously declared, that the business of America is business, then the national conversation about where business is going says a lot about where the country is going. And the business conversation has changed much over the last few months. Our obsession with villains -- Martha, Frank, et al. -- has begun to fade, what with nearly all of them being investigated, tried or convicted, or awaiting sentencing. How long can a country's blood boil? These days, two new stories dominate the headlines and monopolize chatter around the water cooler. And those stories are about heroes: Donald J. Trump, star of the top new television series among adult viewers, and Google's Larry Page and Sergey Brin, stars of the hottest initial public offering in years. It's a back-to-the-future moment. As we struggle to define business in the first decade of the 21st century, we begin by running a rematch of the last two decades of the 20th century. It's the 80's vs. the 90's. ''Greed is good'' vs. ''The Internet changes everything.'' ''The Apprentice'' vs. the Prospectus. The Mogul vs. the Mavericks.

headline.main: Mogul vs. Mavericks: A Search for Heroes

docs.abstract: William C Taylor article says Donald J Trump, star of The Apprentice on television, and Google's founders, Larry Page and Sergey Brin, have become heroes of American business; say Trump does not deserve that status, while Page and Brin do; drawing (L)

docs.snippet: PITY Marc Benioff. Sure, his net worth may well exceed $250 million when Salesforce.com, the company he helped to start in 1999, goes public, most likely in the next couple of months.     But until then, Mr. Benioff, a boyishly brash chief executi...
docs.lead_paragraph: PITY Marc Benioff. Sure, his net worth may well exceed $250 million when Salesforce.com, the company he helped to start in 1999, goes public, most likely in the next couple of months. But until then, Mr. Benioff, a boyishly brash chief executive whose large personality matches his bulky 6-foot-5-inch frame, has to walk around with a government-mandated mute in his mouth -- otherwise known as the quiet period that precedes the sale of stock to the public. That means no boasting to the world about how his company, which might just prove to be the hottest public technology offering this side of Google, will become the Microsoft of the 21st century.

headline.main: It's Not Google. It's That Other Big I.P.O.

docs.abstract: Salesforce.com's usually gregarious chief executive Marc Benioff, officially observing quiet period because of company's planned initial public stock offer, lets reporter follow him around for day, visit that includes hours of one-on-one time; company leases software that provides way of tracking customers and prospective clients; Benioff has become most forceful advocate of model of software as service; photos (M)

docs.snippet: To the idealistic computer scientists who run Google Inc., the company's unusual plan to auction shares in its public offering is both more efficient and fairer than the traditional method in which investment banks set the offering price.     Doub...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the idealistic computer scientists who run Google Inc., the company's unusual plan to auction shares in its public offering is both more efficient and fairer than the traditional method in which investment banks set the offering price. Doubtless, selling shares to the highest bidders would raise the most money from the offering. It would also eliminate the abuses seen in recent years in which bankers gave shares -- at low offering prices that were sure to rise once trading started -- to favored investors and executives.

headline.main: For Google, Going Dutch Has Its Rewards And Its Risks

docs.abstract: Experts say Google Inc's unusual plans to auction shares in its public offering, while producing highest possible offering price, has risks; say such auctions have in some cases caused speculative frenzies that hurt both investors and companies in long run; note auction structure has sometimes eliminated incentive for investors to back new and untested companies, leading to lower-than-expected prices; economists who favor auctions hold benefits far outweigh risks; drawing (M)

docs.snippet: If you type the words ''Google,'' ''stock'' and ''fraud'' into that company's Internet search engine, you will quickly find Shamoon Rafiq.     Last fall, Mr. Rafiq, a native of the Netherlands, got off a plane at Kennedy International Airport and ...
docs.lead_paragraph: If you type the words ''Google,'' ''stock'' and ''fraud'' into that company's Internet search engine, you will quickly find Shamoon Rafiq. Last fall, Mr. Rafiq, a native of the Netherlands, got off a plane at Kennedy International Airport and opened a bank account in New York at HSBC, prosecutors said. Then, demonstrating true entrepreneurial spirit, he began to find investors who were ga-ga for Google.

headline.main: Con Artist Exploited Eagerness for Google, Prosecutors Say

docs.abstract: Shamoon Rafiq, who was arrested in March on wire fraud charges, allegedly conned at least five sophisticated investors, including investment banker and brokerage firm executive, out of $500,000, promising to sell them preferred shares of Google through special 'friends and family' program; he has not been indicted; spent much of money on high living (M)

docs.snippet: AS Google's white-hot initial stock offering hogs the headlines, its rivals can only gnash their teeth and wonder: How did a couple of Stanford Ph.D. dropouts build an outrageously profitable billion-dollar-a-year company in only five years?     P...
docs.lead_paragraph: AS Google's white-hot initial stock offering hogs the headlines, its rivals can only gnash their teeth and wonder: How did a couple of Stanford Ph.D. dropouts build an outrageously profitable billion-dollar-a-year company in only five years? Part of the answer is great Web-search technology. But another part is the company's motto: ''Don't Be Evil.''

headline.main: Google Mail: Virtue Lies In the In-Box

docs.abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on Gmail, free electronic mail being tested by Google; Gmail offers embedded links relevant to e-mail subject and one gigabyte of storage; photo; drawing (M)

docs.snippet: Google, the Web search engine which attracted a loyal following in part because its simple Web site is uncluttered by obtrusive graphical banner ads, has now decided to sell the sort of ads it once scorned.    The graphic ads will not appear on Go...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google, the Web search engine which attracted a loyal following in part because its simple Web site is uncluttered by obtrusive graphical banner ads, has now decided to sell the sort of ads it once scorned. The graphic ads will not appear on Google.com for now. But they will appear on the sites of other Web publishers where Google sells advertising. That segment of ad sales is a fast-growing part of Google's business. Until now, the advertisements on other sites have been a few words of text and a link to the advertisers' Web site.

headline.main: Google to Sell Type of Ad It Once Shunned

docs.abstract: Google, Web search engine, decides to sell graphic banner ads, which it once scorned; graphic ads will not appear on Google.com for now, but will appear on sites of other Web publishers where Google sells advertising (M)

docs.snippet: Edging closer to a direct confrontation with Microsoft, Google, the Web search engine, is preparing to introduce a powerful file and text software search tool for locating information stored on personal computers.    Google's software, which is ex...
docs.lead_paragraph: Edging closer to a direct confrontation with Microsoft, Google, the Web search engine, is preparing to introduce a powerful file and text software search tool for locating information stored on personal computers. Google's software, which is expected to be introduced soon, according to several people with knowledge of the company's plans, is the clearest indication to date that the company, based in Mountain View, Calif., hopes to extend its search business to compete directly with Microsoft's control of desktop computing.

headline.main: Google Moves Toward Clash With Microsoft

docs.abstract: Google, edging closer to direct confrontation with Microsoft, is preparing to introduce powerful file and text software search tool for locating information stored on personal computers; Google's software is clearest indication that company hopes to extend its search business to compete directly with Microsoft's control of desktop computing; improved technology for searching information stored on personal computer will also be crucial feature of Microsoft's long-delayed version of its Windows operating system called Longhorn, which is not expected before 2006 at earliest (M)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''Google Mail: Virtue Lies in the In-Box'' (State of the Art, May 13) does a very good job of laying out some of the excellent features of Google's proposal for a free e-mail service, Gmail, which the company is now beta-testing....
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Google Mail: Virtue Lies in the In-Box'' (State of the Art, May 13) does a very good job of laying out some of the excellent features of Google's proposal for a free e-mail service, Gmail, which the company is now beta-testing. However, it leaves out the most important problem with the program, one that I have drafted a state bill to address.

headline.main: Google Mail and Prying Eyes

docs.abstract: Letter from California State Sen Liz Figueroa who is drafting legislation that will force Google to notify senders of e-mail to users of its new Gmail that their communications are subject to analysis (May 13 article)

docs.snippet: You might call it the Yahooing of Google. Seeking to build on the popularity of its Web search tool, Google has added features and worked to make others more appealing to non-techies. It recently rolled out a streamlined version of Blogger (www.bl...
docs.lead_paragraph: You might call it the Yahooing of Google. Seeking to build on the popularity of its Web search tool, Google has added features and worked to make others more appealing to non-techies. It recently rolled out a streamlined version of Blogger (www.blogger.com), one of the most popular services for publishing the online journals known as Web logs. The overhaul is the first since Google bought the service 15 months ago. With some of the changes, Blogger is trying to catch competitors like LiveJournal. For example, visitors to a blog made with Blogger can now leave comments on specific entries. New profile pages with information about the person behind the blog make it easier to find people with similar interests, much as on social networking sites like Friendster.

headline.main: To Woo Impatient Novices, Google Tweaks Its Blogger

docs.abstract: Blogger from Google is free service intended for non-techie people to begin blogging; photo (M)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''Don't be evil.'' That motto should be applied to every Web company out there. I hope to see more unobtrusive innovations from Google.    Jason Neufeld  Lewiston, N.Y....
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Don't be evil.'' That motto should be applied to every Web company out there. I hope to see more unobtrusive innovations from Google. Jason Neufeld Lewiston, N.Y.

headline.main: Google Mail and Prying Eyes

docs.abstract: Jason Neufeld letter comments on May 13 article on Google's new electronic mail feature

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''Google Mail: Virtue Lies in the In-Box'' (State of the Art, May 13) brushed aside serious privacy concerns. Although advertisements are inserted into incoming Gmail by computer, it is not true that ''no human ever looks at the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Google Mail: Virtue Lies in the In-Box'' (State of the Art, May 13) brushed aside serious privacy concerns. Although advertisements are inserted into incoming Gmail by computer, it is not true that ''no human ever looks at the Gmail e-mail,'' as the article asserted. Gmail's privacy policy states that ''A limited set of employees are authorized to access user accounts'' for, among other things, undefined ''internal business purposes.''

headline.main: Google Mail and Prying Eyes

docs.abstract: Hamish Anderson letter scores May 13 article on Gmail from Google for giving only passing mention to fact that Google employees may indeed be accessing user e-mail accounts

docs.snippet: ''WHAT'S that movie where the guy says, 'Plastics -- there's a great future in plastics'?'' John Maeda asks me. Before waiting for me to say ''The Graduate,'' he adds, ''I feel like that guy.''     If he were truly the Mr. McGuire of the 21st cent...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''WHAT'S that movie where the guy says, 'Plastics -- there's a great future in plastics'?'' John Maeda asks me. Before waiting for me to say ''The Graduate,'' he adds, ''I feel like that guy.'' If he were truly the Mr. McGuire of the 21st century, he'd be touting Google or biometrics, but I see the parallel. Dr. Maeda, an associate professor of design and computation at the M.I.T. Media Lab and an award-winning graphic designer, has spent eight months putting forward his own one-word vision of the future: simplicity.

headline.main: A Design Epiphany: Keep It Simple

docs.abstract: Simplicity Design Workshop at MIT Media Lab is set up for working designers to collaborate with researchers on simplification of technology in increasingly complex world; helps researchers focus less on technology and more on user's vital needs; photo (M)

docs.snippet: The State of the Art column in Circuits on May 13, about an e-mail service developed by Google, referred incorrectly to an appeal by privacy advocates concerned about the service, and it omitted the names of some groups joining the appeal. The gro...
docs.lead_paragraph: The State of the Art column in Circuits on May 13, about an e-mail service developed by Google, referred incorrectly to an appeal by privacy advocates concerned about the service, and it omitted the names of some groups joining the appeal. The groups, citing California's wiretapping laws, urged an investigation of the service, not a shutdown. The letter was signed by the Privacy Rights Clearinghouse and the World Privacy Forum, not just the Electronic Privacy Information Center. The column also included an outdated reference to California legislation prompted by such concerns. As amended, the bill would allow some scanning of e-mail contents by service providers; it would not make it illegal to filter out pornography.

headline.main: Corrections

docs.abstract: Correction of May 13 State of the Art column in Circuits about e-mail service developed by Google, regarding names of some privacy advocates appealing for investigation of service
docs.section_name: Technology; Corrections; New York and Region

docs.snippet: Google Inc. amended its $2.718 billion initial public offering on Friday, adding 29 underwriters and revising some of the financial information in the form.      The original document, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on April 29,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google Inc. amended its $2.718 billion initial public offering on Friday, adding 29 underwriters and revising some of the financial information in the form. The original document, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on April 29, named Credit Suisse First Boston and Morgan Stanley & Company as the lead underwriters for the initial public offering, one of the most closely watched financial events in Silicon Valley history. In the new document, investment firms like Allen & Company, Citigroup Global Markets and Goldman, Sachs were added as well as technology-centric companies like W.R. Hambrecht & Company and E*Trade Securities.

headline.main: Google Revises Data in Public Offering and Adds 29 Underwriters

docs.abstract: Google Inc amends its $2.718 billion initial public offering, adding 29 underwriters and revising some of financial information on form; Google also discloses new information on its international revenue, which reached 29 percent of total sales during most recent quarter; Google filing indicates that company's two founders, Sergey Brin and Larry Page, each own about 16 percent of company; based on valuations of $20 billion to $30 billion, that would put their individual net worth at $3 billion to $4.7 billion (S)

docs.snippet: Any suggestion of profitless, no-product companies with ambitious dreams might sound like ''Son of Dot-com'' to investors who were burned when the Internet bubble burst. Yet a few companies in nanotechnology are confident they can offer just that ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Any suggestion of profitless, no-product companies with ambitious dreams might sound like ''Son of Dot-com'' to investors who were burned when the Internet bubble burst. Yet a few companies in nanotechnology are confident they can offer just that -- big promises and no proof of earnings -- to investors hungry for a stake in a hot new sector. Last month, Nanosys Inc., a company in Palo Alto, Calif., filed a public offering statement hoping to raise up to $115 million. Unlike Google Inc., its Silicon Valley neighbor that is also going public, Nanosys has no profits and no products to sell, and its filing statement said it would not market any products before 2006.

headline.main: Going Public Without Profits Or a Product? Yes, in 2004

docs.abstract: Some analysts say stock offering by Nanosys Inc, company with no products or profits, could spur similar offerings by other nanotechnology startups; excitement over nanotechnology, broad term for technical advances in handling materials at molecular level, differs in some key respects from earlier dot-com mania; field has garnered billions of dollars in federal research support; Nanosys has over 200 patents and patent applications as well as product development ventures with big companies (M)
